thread.title: Dunedoo fire recovery underway thanks to Blazeaid
thread.title_full: Dunedoo fire recovery underway thanks to Blazeaid

title: Dunedoo fire recovery underway thanks to Blazeaid
text:
Map: Dunedoo 2844 
Volunteer organisation BlazeAid started rebuilding fences at Dunedoo over the weekend with more than 100 people travelling from the Scone region of New South Wales. 
They brought fencing equipment with them, including front-end loaders and bobcats, to help landholders recover from recent bushfires . 
Dunedoo farmer Saxon McGregor lost all his pastures and fencing and said he deeply appreciated the help. 
"These guys are just doing a wonderful job...a better job than I can do in many cases," he said. 
"I mean, they are welding up these steel end sections. It's just a beautiful job." Photo: BlazeAid volunteers prepare meals for the fencing crews who have started the rebuilding task on farms affected by fires. (ABC Rural: Michael Cavanagh) 
While Mr McGregor's house at Cairn Hill on the Golden Highway near Uarbry survived the fires, across the highway neighbour Chris Wentworth Brown lost everything, including his house. 
He is now dividing his time between living in an old caravan on the property and a house in nearby Dunedoo where his wife and children are staying. 
Mr Wentworth Brown said he had only taken his children back to the property once. 
"I don't think need to see much more wrack and ruin. They were walking around with ash in their eyes," he said. 
"They had to see it, but I don't think they need it rubbed in their faces any more." 
Kyle Fullford, who has a rural contracting business in Maitland, pulled a team of other contractors together to help out. 
He said he was deeply affected by seeing properties affected by the fires. 
"It was breathtaking [and] until you see it, you can't explain," Mr Fullford said. 
"It's very sad to be honest." Photo: Some of the cattle sold at Dunedoo will be fattened and sold off to raise money for the recovery effort. (ABC Rural: Michael Cavanagh) 
He said some fencing materials had been donated by large companies or purchased through cash donations. 
Mr Fullford is hoping others will come forward and volunteer to continue with the work when his team has to leave. 
"I thought 'let's give back to the farmers who give us so much'," he said.
